lines: Take the survey, linked here.

Find a laptop. Figure out which laptop you're going to bring with you to class with you every day, starting on the day this assignment is due. If this is a hardship, see Mr. Smith immediately; we will find a good solution.
Install Atom on your laptop. Installation instructions are linked here.
Then in Atom *change your theme* and *turn on Soft Wrap* using the info in the middle of the page linked here
Your classmates and I will expect that you have successfully installed Atom and that you are ready to use it before the class when this assignment is due. Thanks!
Read Blown To Bits Chapter 1 (linked here).
In Piazza create a new "Note" (folder "0-intro") and write 100-200 words about how one part of the reading is relevant to you as a student at WUHS.
Be prepared to discuss the entire reading next class.
Finish FirstBlog
Finish Codecademy Lesson "Intro to HTML"
<del>Compile your "two morals" notes into a second blog post.</del> (cancelled at the end of class 09/07)

create a second blog post on your blog, in which you answer (in 100-200 words) the question you took notes on in class last week: "What does a good citizen look like in a world where the Bits authors 'two basic morals' exist?" (book pg 14, pdf pg 17)
return signed research consent form (regardless of your decision to participate)
collect survey data from 5 people not in this class
click one of the 'full article' buttons linked on ACM TechNews, read the full article, and be ready to verbally summarize and discuss it next class
write 200-300 word summary of your ACM TechNews article (which you read over the weekend) and add it to your blog as a new blog post
read/do Images 1 and 1.5 and 2 (links in resources)
post a Piazza note to instructor only with screenshot of Image 2 exercises (code+image)
do IntroComputing exercises for Image 3, Image 4, and Image 5 (including the "optional" one)
post a Piazza note to instructor only with screenshots of the code+images from the Image 5 exercises
do IntroComputing exercises for Image 6
post a Piazza note to instructor only with screenshots of the code+images from the Image 6 exercises
return field trip form

Do Level 10 of the Turtle Blockly Game on your own. Take a screenshot of your Level 10 image and your code, and post it as a public note to Piazza. (start this in class on Tuesday, and work with the partner assigned Monday this week)
Do Image 7 exercises

Study vocab here then create Flipgrid video (link 1 for students working on the Lobby Screen team) (link 2 for students working on the Word Count Viz team) (link 3 for students working on the Randomizer team)
optional: do Image 8 exercises. post screenshots of your code + images on Piazza as a private note to instructor
Finish or make visible progress on your WCS sprint task (see notecards on your scrum board)

Create your own 'fake news' image using the Custom Bluescreen link at IntroComputing.com. On Piazza, post all of the following in one public note: (1) all three of your images (image, back, and result), and (2) a copy/paste of the text of your code (not a screenshot like before), and (3) a short 'fake news' headline to accompany your image, and (4) a short (max 200 words) description of the incremental development process of your program, focusing on one difficulty you encountered and how you resolved it.

Edit shared slide deck linked here. Create two new slides: one has your final image and your headline (in large font). The second has your revised description (taking into account your colleagues' suggestions on Piazza) of difficulty and resolution.
study for test: abstraction, your WCS product (what is its purpose), where have you been creative, flipgrid questions, internet vocab (see links below)
read this and summarize it in a new blog post on github (means, update your FirstBlog page so that it contains a new post)
do Puzzles 1-3 from Lesson 6. work solo or with pair programming
do Puzzles 1-10 from Lesson 7. work solo or with pair programming
do Puzzles 12-15 from Lesson 7
do Puzzles 1-7 and 10-16 from Lesson 8. work solo or with pair programming
do Puzzles 2-15 from Lesson 9
(Gardner, Tierney, Matt: Lesson 7 #12-15, Lesson 9 #2-15)
do these practice AP questions: Lesson 6 #4, Lesson 7 #11, Lesson 8 #18-20, Lesson 9 #16-19
classwork: WCS Products: DIY-HW make a task card for what you will accomplish outside of class by next Friday 8AM
classwork: write a paragraph in which you make connections between the four main concepts from the 'Design a Digital Scene' project (Abstractions, Functions, Top-Down Design, and Collaboration)
classwork: code.org assessment lesson 3 #1-4: do and review
required homework: finish your Design a Digital Scene project, if you haven't already
optional homework: write some multiple-choice turtle problems like the one we did in class. make one that's very tricky
due 8am Friday morning: finish the WCS Products task you defined for yourself, and move the card to 'Done'
finish anything from this week's classtime agendas that you didn't get done in class (listed in the following bullets)

ask the sub for a copy of CSP Unit 3 Assessment Solutions #1-4, which is on Mr. Smith's desk. Read #3 and 4 (and #1 and 2 if you weren't in class last time). Try to understand why the given answer is correct. In the 'For Teachers Only' part of each question, underline the most important parts. Put a question mark next to anything you don't understand. Put your name on the packet and put it in Mr. Smith's inbox

ask the sub for the Ghosts in the Machine reading. Read Pgs #73 - 80. As you're reading, on a blank sheet of paper, write down at least one main point from each page. After you're done reading pgs 73-80, write two or three questions about the article which you think could lead to interesting discussion.
watch and answer the questions in these videos (in this order): (1) (2) (3)
do the two practice sheets that are on my desk (Practice with Number Systems 2 and Practice with Number Systems 3)
prepare for test Thursday about number systems (convert among bin <-> dec <-> hex)
make a poster showing how to convert from hex or bin (you pick one) to dec ... (we'll start this assignment in class Tuesday, then it's due Thursday)

read Ghosts in the Machine pgs 80-99 (get a paper copy in classroom or read it online here) and email Mr. Smith two questions you think would make for interesting discussion (we'll have a discussion about the reading in class Thursday, and there will probably be a couple questions about the reading on the test)
watch this final video about binary. basic questions about it will be on the test Thursday.

do code.org Unit *5* Lesson 1, pages 1-22 (page 23 is optional). this might take a while, so plan ahead and use your Thursday class time well. Please do not use the 'pair programming' mode offered by code.org, but I do encourage you to work alongside with someone and talk through what you're doing, just both of you should be typing on your own machines.

do code.org Unit *5* Lesson 2, pages 1-15. Please do not use the 'pair programming' mode offered by code.org, but I do encourage you to work alongside with someone and talk through what you're doing, but both of you should be typing on your own machines.
Create a multi-screen app here, meeting the six requirements listed in the Activity Guide (paper you got in class)

TD, ME, GG ... do this instead: start with your game code, and repurpose it into an AI for 1-player Tic-Tac-Toe. Allow multiple games and include some text or visual which explains to the user what the computer is doing to learn how to play better)
code.org Unit 5 finish Lessons 4 and 5
TD, ME, GG ... do this instead: add functionality for AI vs AI in Game of Sticks OR in Tic Tac Toe
finish midterm project (see handout given in class)
finish Code.org Unit 5 Lesson 6 'User Input and Strings'
finish 'Will It Crash' packet pages 1-4
finish Code.org Unit 5 Lesson 8 'Boolean Expressions and If Statements'

TD, ME, GG: instead of that, your job is to each take a copy of your current bot and enhance it somehow. put your enhanced bot on github and email me a link to the repo. at the start of next class we'll play them against each other
do Code.org Unit 5 Lesson 9, not the whole lesson only Pages 1-7 ... and yes, it's unlocked and visible :-)
<strike>TD</strike>, ME, GG: instead of that, work on your robot. only 48 hours left til final submission. this means you gotta have something workable at the start of next class.
do Code.org Unit 5 Lesson 10, pages 1-21
TD, ME, GG: instead of that, submit your robot to the high school tournament by 3pm Wednesday, then visit me to report completion!
review Survival Guide pgs 1-10, do pages 11 & 12 (make guesses, estimations, or predictions where you need to on page 12)
decide on your project
set up your development environment
write 5 lines of code
spend 40 minutes coding your Create PT project
Tierney, Gardner, Matt: complete your Battlecode Retrospective, shared with you in gdrive, and email me when you're done
spend 60 minutes coding your Create PT project
Tuesday will be your last classday to work on the CreatePT. The final project with all requirements is due Thursday at 8am. We will go over 'how to submit' in class Tuesday.
